fields.content: The Floodplain Gravel Mine Restoration Assessment Tool
We are building an online tool that provides an efficient and sound approach to quickly identify whether restoring a former gravel pit mine location is worth the investment of time and money.
The Floodplain Gravel Mine Restoration Assessment Tool

Informed decision making and resource investment
for the restoration of floodplain mining locations.

Click anywhere on the map to start defining your general location boundary.

Continue clicking to complete the shape of your location.

When you're satisfied with your location outline, double-click to end drawing.

Name and save your location when done. You can come back and edit this at any time.

Click and hold anywhere on the location border to grab it.

Drag the section of border to where it belongs.

Site: A contiguous plot of land that encompasses one or more pits.

Pit: A single gravel pit mine.
Like drawing your location, click once on the map to begin drawing your pit boundaries. Click again to add additional points. Double-click to finish.
Click and hold anywhere on the pit border to grab it. Drag the section of the border to where it belongs.
This tool is a product of The Nature Conservancy and Ecotrust

Before you get started...

Please assemble as many of the following resources as possible:

Taxlot, land user, easement, access, infrastructure, and other relevant location information.

Any information on existing permits or pit reclaimation requirements

Existing conservation plans, recovery plans, prioritizations, regional priorities

Water rights information

State environment or water quality information

Watershed assessments, sediment budgets, and other available watershed or river research, reports, or data

Ecological assessments, research, reports, or data on species and habitat in the watershed, the reach, or on the location

Reasonable estimates of both pit depth and river thalweg
